comments.commentBody: Roger Stone! Welcome to the NYT comments section! Sure that wasn't a receipt to the Bunny Ranch, Rog?
Unlikely! Thanks for your article, but hopefully unlikely. Please don't stir it up!

Exactly, this article is irresponsible.  Unless a real revolution is taking place, even talking about it is extreme foolishness.  A better article would have been one that contrasted the many things we share in common with our political opponents.

Dear Brenda Wallace,
I share your anger. I share your rage. I understand it. I understand your desire to grab a weapon. I too, have felt that way. Often.
But I also remember. I remember history. I remember the history of 150 years ago. I remember over 600 thousand mothers sons DEAD. I remember hundreds of thousands more, maimed and mutilated for life.
And I remember, that all of that sacrifice - all those who gave the full measure of devotion - did not solve the problem.
I remember - history.

The media plays upon potential disaster as it stirs interest and get people to interact on the potentially nothing issue. Let us hope that it is a nothing but we must prepare and address it to make sure that it is a "nothing". Mr. Trump has tapped fully into the hate built by right-wing conservative media for decades and there is a lot of reactionary opposition that is almost at an explosion level in that opposition.

It is now time for good leaders to lead, to defuse and to plant the seeds of respect. Mr. Trump has repeatedly decided to take the low roads so we must continue to take the high roads but WATCH CAREFULLY that traffic on those low roads. We cannot commit folly for it could be at our peril. Watch, walk and talk softly but carry a big stick that you are willing to use if it is necessary.

Very interesting though it doesnt work to extrapolate from Vermont Town Hall meetings to ALL scenarios when women speak professionally.  I have worked under numerous female bosses and when they talked to a group, their staff people listened.  Sexism is the USA is quite real but the nuances of that sexism is definitely more complicated than this one very limited study suggests.

This is certainly a conundrum that is facing MLB. There is certainly a dearth of white managers who were selected over very capable non-whites. I am most familiar with the case of Willie Randolph, who managed the Mets in there city
that I reside in. I believe very much that he was given the "shaft," and not
allowed to demonstrate his full managerial talents. He most certainly deserves another chance.

The writer conveniently forgets that Willie Randolph's tenure, was marked by talented teams that fell apart in 2007 and 2008, notable September collapses that might impair his future employability as a manager. Mr. Randolph was followed by another minority manager, Jerry Manuel, who had less talented squads and was less successful. During this time, the Mets' GM was Omar Minya, a Latino gentleman from Corona. To pick on the Mets is simply unfair and inaccurate. It is more than possible that other teams should consider promoting the black coaches they have for running the major league franchise. If every team was as fair-minded as the Wilpons, who own the Mets, in minority coach hiring, this article would not be written.

I was basically about to write the same comment. I love Randolph but Willie becoming "testy and brittle" was his reaction to adversity. I do add that the article documents a serious problem if you like watching a sport whose corporate structure you'd like to have respect for (to answer another commenter who says "who cares?"). Other Mets minority coaches include Sandy Alomar Sr, Sandy Alomar Jr and currently Tom Goodwin. I expect I'm leaving someone out. It's just odd, a NY newspaper singling out the Mets on the topic,  and not mentioning our Yankees. The Yankees did have Bob Watson do a terrific job as General Manager but that ended 20 years ago. I'm probably leaving someone out, but Tony Pena was considered but passed over as field manager and his transition from bench coach to first base coach (I don't understand how that's not a demotion) suggests he's not going to be considered again. Pena has a major league managing resume to go with the respect he earned as NYY bench coach (not from the team  apparently). I hope he gets another chance somewhere.

I think you're missing Powell's point. He didn't say that the Mets had no reason fire Randolph; to the contrary, he noted that this was the fate of almost all managers. His point, as I read it, was that nobody has since given Randolph the kind of second chance that has been given to numerous white managers who failed on their first go-round (including the Mets' current manager).

It's all about the violence! The concussions; and threat of concussions by violent men using there helmeted heads to "butt" another player....
Look at the recent damage to Seahawks QB, Russell Wilson....

By the way, I'm a 65 year old white male who's watched pro football avidly for the past 55 years! And I have reduced my viewing NFL games in half this season...... mostly because the violence (esp. to QB's - and WR's)
is almost criminal!
Along with the recent publicity on player concussions over the years has really resonated with me!

Meh, get over yourselves. I hated Reagan and Bush, the son. Could not stand neither the sight nor sound of them.

I spent 16 years changing the channel. That was my revolution.

You can't always get what you want. I've been waiting 63 years for a fair, equal, non- discriminatory society. Still waiting. I've never owed a gun and have no plans to do so. Never rioted.

Suck it up. Be happy men in leather boots sent by your government won't come knocking on your door in the dead of night. Be happy you don't get a leader for life.

These idiots don't know that's just where they're taking us.
I am ready wherever they take us.
A VW bus sped by?  Sir, I doubt your story based on factual inaccuracies.

Much ado about nothing.

In 2008, many Southern Whites said they would move to Canada if Obama won the Presidency, they are still here.

Obama is now a twice elected President and still no Revolution.

When Trump loses, he and his supporters, will simply go back to watching Fox News.

Revolutions take a lot of work and brains but remember…we are taking about Trump supporters.
As if Canada would have them.
Well they didn't say Trump attracted less well educated voters without having a reason.
The American Revolution usured in a democratic republic. I suspect the Founders would not support a revolution to overthrow a legally elected POTUS.

Trump supporters take heart, our country has been through worse than this election and our nation will stand. Trump doesn't care about this country or you. And the 2nd amendment is safe. Research what it takes to overturn it and you realize no President has that power.

Republican leaders have already voiced their plan if Hillary wins...Utah Republican Jason Chaffetz has lined up enough material from Sec. Clinton's four years in service to have two more years of probes. They plan on blocking any Supreme Court nominees and I'm quite sure they won't stop there. Please Americans vote these idiots out of office for the good of your nation and the rest of the world.

Saving Capitalism - Robert Reich's book - is one to read on this topic.
Read the NYT Times review of it.

"not our enemies" is different from "friends." In my life I've worked successfully with people for whom I had very little respect and zero affection. What makes all the difference is having common goals: meeting that deadline, coming in at or under budget, finding and fixing that coding problem, etc. If we want to build something in this country, we can. And we don't have to be besties to do it. We DO have to define our common goals and put our minds into achieving them. We DO have to act like adults. For some people, that seems to be impossible.

Where I came from, if I was to tell an old friend, he's revolting, and at the same time, I told him to tell his wife, hi, I'd be in a lot of trouble! And it's not because I support Hillary, or that I called him, revolting!!!

Evangelical Christians and Yiddish insults. I've heard the term but it was, at least, used by a man whose first language was Yiddish. He was, despite his use of the word (we all know what it was), a good man. He made his own way in the world from the time he was probably about 12. (We could not pin him down on his age, but knew he was telling the truth. Daddy didn't give him millions when he turned 21.)

It scares me that otherwise smart people, mostly men, support Trump. Remember that not all smart people went to college or even finished high school. Some of us had to go to work. That's part of the lottery of birth. It's got nothing to do with being smart.

You are so right. There are many friends who I'll never quite see in the same way again. Much like my best friend (at least at the time) who, in reference to Obama, looked me right in the eye and said "But he's black!" I was flabbergasted and literally speechless; this is an educated woman who I never would have dreamed would ever say anything like that. That was 8 years ago and I've not felt the same way about her since; something died that day.

It wasn't until later that I realized that her personality change coincided with her "getting religion." I wish these people would ask themselves what Jesus would do.

Ridiculous and childlike. Years ago I learned to just delete those crazy emails.  You cannot change the demented minds that are ideological nut jobs on both sides. Take a deep breath and enjoy life. It's too short to obsess over this.

Love is one thing, but respect doesn't always come with it. My question to the author would be how he can respect an educated man who believes Trump would do a good job of running the country? It's truly an indefensible position, and I would never look at a friend the same way after this revelation. Yes, outside of politics your friend may be a great guy, but ultimately he is making an extremely reckless choice that directly affects the rest of us. I'd like to buy into the friendship-conquers-all concept, but it makes no sense.

The US and Russian nuclear arsenals are, essentially, still on hair-trigger alert despite the Cold War having ended over 20 years ago. And the biggest danger in having a belligerent and confusing person (i.e. Donald Trump), as Commander-in-Chief of the US Nuclear Arsenal, comes from the potential that such a person would have for accidentally causing the use of nuclear weapons by Russia, against the United States.

I would ask others to take a look at a paper titled ‘Accidental Nuclear War – The Real Danger of a Donald Trump Presidency’ which is posted at www.nucleardanger.org and that discusses this in more detail.
Hillary's "atrocities"? Seriously?
Hillary is responsible for the deaths of 4!Americans in Benghazi---that is an strosity---times four.  Just ask the families of those four patriots!
She is responsible?  Seriously?

Edward, there have been EIGHT investigations into Benghazi and they have turned up nothing. Either the committee is pathetically inept or there really is nothing there. I believe the latter: there is nothing there, but they keep trying because they're doing a smear campaign.

The family of Christopher Stevens emphatically does not blame Hillary or anyone in the Obama administration: http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/chris-stevenss-family-dont-blame...
This is a strong, real, honest, human essay. Thank you for writing it. Anyone with friends and family we love, but whose politics infuriate us will see themselves here.
